com.hazelcast.internal.networking.nonblocking

Class NonBlockingSocketReader

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.hazelcast.internal.networking.nonblocking.AbstractHandler
      • com.hazelcast.internal.networking.nonblocking.NonBlockingSocketReader
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    MigratableHandler, SelectionHandler, SocketReader

    public final class NonBlockingSocketReader
extends AbstractHandler
implements SocketReader
    A SocketReader tailored for non blocking IO. When the NonBlockingIOThread receives a read event from the Selector, then the handle() is called to read out the data from the socket into a bytebuffer and hand it over to the ReadHandler to get processed.

      • init

        public void init()
        Description copied from interface: SocketReader

        init in interface SocketReader

      • requestMigration

        public void requestMigration(NonBlockingIOThread newOwner)
        Migrates this handler to a new NonBlockingIOThread. The migration logic is rather simple:

        • Submit a de-registration task to a current NonBlockingIOThread
        • The de-registration task submits a registration task to the new NonBlockingIOThread

        Specified by:
        requestMigration in interface MigratableHandler
        Parameters:
        newOwner - target NonBlockingIOThread this handler migrates to

      • handle

        public void handle()
            throws Exception
        Description copied from interface: SelectionHandler
        Called when there are bytes available for reading, or space available to write. Any exception that leads to a termination of the connection like an IOException should not be handled in the handle method but should be propagated. The reason behind this is that the handle logic already is complicated enough and by pulling it out the flow will be easier to understand.
        Specified by:
        handle in interface SelectionHandler
        Throws:
        Exception

      • close

        public void close()
        Description copied from interface: SocketReader
        Closes this SocketReader. This method can be called from an arbitrary thread, and should only be called once. This should be coordinated through the Connection.close(String, Throwable) method.
        Specified by:
        close in interface SocketReader

        public String toString()
